Covered bridge over the Conestoga near Eden. Note the almost perfect reflection in the water.
Covered bridge over the Conestoga river, with a note about its nearly perfect reflection on the surface of the water below it. The location is specified as being close to Eden and near the Conestoga River.
Bleak farm land in November. Looking north from the New Holland Pike in the direction of Hunsicker Mill.
Landis Valley Museum where are preserved many of the articles of every day life in the early days of the county. The street car, shown at right, made its last appearance in 1947.
WHEATLAND, home of James Buchanan, seventeenth president of the United States. Located on Marietta Avenue.

blocks.text: A home in the river hills.

Some of the most interesting scenery in Lancaster County
scenery in Lancaster County is found along Pequea Creek as it winds through the river hills approaching the Susque-
hanna River.
The picture at the right shows The bridge over Pequea Creek
at Colemanville. By following by following the Creek on foot back in the direction of Martic Forge you discover the spots shown on
the following page.
Looking through the covered bridge shown in the large picture above.
Path along a brook which flows into the Pequea Creek.

blocks.text:
We failed to have a white Christmas in 1947,
but snow fell the next day.
Cindy and Kathy accompanied Gordon on a drive along the Conestoga to the water. works late in December. The stone bridge carries the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad from Philadelphia.

blocks.text:
Mid–February. The Susquehanna River is frozen solid from shore to shore. Note the figures far out on the River.
The Susquehannaehannahna River is from shore to shore too, but note the figures fair out on the river.
The ice jam on the Pequea Creek near Colemanville. The day after this picture was taken the road was covered by three feet of water resulting from a sudden thaw.
Approach tto covered bridge over the Little Conestoga Creek west of Millersville.

This is the Cocalico along the road from Brownstown to Rothsville.
Kathy appproaches the bridge over the Cocalico near Log Cabin.

blocks.text:
On the road between Maytown and Bainbridge we come upon the hamlet of Lobata and this old stone arch bridge over the Conoy Creek. The picture below was taken from a bluff overlooking the Creek.
The Conoy derives its name from the Conoy or Canowese Indians who lived in this section in the first half of the eighteenth century.
Pictures taken in mid-March, 1948

pages.full_text:
On the road between Maytown and Bainbridge we come upon the hamlet of Lobata and this old stone arch bridge over the Conoy Creek. The picture below was taken from a bluff overlooking the Creek.
The Conoy derives its name from the Conoy or Canowese Indians who lived in this section in the first half of the eighteenth century.
Pictures taken in mid-March, 1948

blocks.text: A visit to Cornwall Furnace in early April. Built by Curtis Grubb and later operated by the Coleman family; in continuous operation from 1742 to 1885. During the Revolution the Grubb iron works were munition plants of the Continental army. Cannon, shot and shell were cast here, and detachments of Hessian prisoners were sent here for employment.

The hugh ore quarry,
from which more than 20,000,000 tons have been taken.
Old sandstone church at Cornwall.
Cornwall Furnace, which has been turned over to the State by the Coleman heirs.
Spring reveries.
Old spring house north of McGovernsville.

blocks.text: DONEGAL PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH; organized 1714; present church erected about 1740. The picture at lower left shows the famous "Witness Tree". On a Sunday morning in September, 1777 an express rider came to tell the congregation of Donegal Church that the British under Lord Howe had left New York to invade Pennsylvania. When this news was received by the pastor, the Reverend Colin McFarquhar, and congregation gathered under this tree, and together joined hands and pledged their loyalty to the cause of liberty and the founding of a new nation. (From a tablet erected at the tree.)

blocks.text: TRIP TO WEST VIRGINIA AND VIRGINIA, April 17 and 18, Claude and Betty Smith, Kitty and Gordon. FIRST DAY: left Lancaster about 8:30 A. M; to York, to Gettysburg, to Waynesboro, to Hagerstown, to Cumberland, southwest through Keyser to Elkins, W. Va. SECOND DAY: east from Elk-ins over the mountains to Mouth of Seneca, north to Corners, then south again through the Smoke Hole region to Franklin, east into Virginia at Harrisonburg, north through the Shenandoah Valley to Winch-ester, to Charles Town and Harpers Ferry, to Hanover, York and home.
On teh first day we made lunch over on a charcoal stove beside this sparkling stream, just beyond Keyser in West Virginia. Kitty, Gordon and Claude.

blocks.text: Views from the fire tower on the top of Bickle Knob. Distances of forty to fifty miles can be seen.

The road south from Corners in the Smoke Hole valley is built along the side of the mountains. We were told it has been in operation only about eight years. The whole region is lonely and isolated. We wondered how people ever managed to get out of these mountains before the road was built. We had a suspicion many of them never did. The road is gravel, in good repair.-This area should be covered on any trip through this section.

blocks.text: Hugh masses of solid rock, with the rushing waters of the South Branch River (Potomac) are found in the Smoke Hole region. For almost two hundred years this section was without roads and the inhabitants hemmed in by the lofty, surrounding mountains.

Many of the people of the Smoke Hole still live as their ancestors lived in the years before the Revolution—ary War. Hard liquor from private stills located here has been a commodity for a long time. Land is poor, and is purchasable for a dollar or two an acre.

blocks.text:
The top of Shenandoah Mountain
is the dividing line between West Virginia and Virginia. The mountain scenery is out-standing on both sides.

STATE OF VIRGINIA
Named for Queen Elizabeth, the Virgin Queen of England. Site of the first permanent English settlement in America, 1607 One of the L3 original colonies. The Old Dominion is the birthplace of eight United States Presidents.
SHENANDOAH MT. ELEVATION 3450 FT.

After leaving Harrisonburg, we made a quick trip up the Shenandoah Valley to Winchester. Most of the apple trees, for which this section is justly famous, were in bloom. From Winchester we headed east to Charles Town and Harpers Ferry, where John Brown conducted his famous raid prior to the Civil War. Picture at left shows some of the old houses in Harpers Ferry. At right is the view of the rivers from the hill top at Harpers Ferry.
Here Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia meet.
The region north and east of Frederick is richly agricul-tural, all the way to Hanover and York. The well kept farms and farm buildings compare favorably with those in Lancaster County.
End - trip to West Virginia.

pages.caption_text:
The top of Shenandoah Mountain
is the dividing line between West Virginia and Virginia. The mountain scenery is out-standing on both sides.

STATE OF VIRGINIA
Named for Queen Elizabeth, the Virgin Queen of England. Site of the first permanent English settlement in America, 1607 One of the L3 original colonies. The Old Dominion is the birthplace of eight United States Presidents.

SHENANDOAH MT. ELEVATION 3450 FT.

After leaving Harrisonburg, we made a quick trip up the Shenandoah Valley to Winchester. Most of the apple trees, for which this section is justly famous, were in bloom. From Winchester we headed east to Charles Town and Harpers Ferry, where John Brown conducted his famous raid prior to the Civil War. Picture at left shows some of the old houses in Harpers Ferry. At right is the view of the rivers from the hill top at Harpers Ferry.
Here Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia meet.

The region north and east of Frederick is richly agricul-tural, all the way to Hanover and York. The well kept farms and farm buildings compare favorably with those in Lancaster County.

End - trip to West Virginia.

blocks.text: Lancaster County's bountiful farm land.

A visit to Cutler's Point, a lookout 400 feet above the Susquehanna River near Fishing Creek. Pennsylvania and Maryland meet where the river narrows. The wooded island is Mt. Johnson Bald Eagle Sanctuary.
